frontmatter.author: Desmond Tutu
frontmatter.quote: Differences are not intended to separate, to alienate. We are different precisely in order to realize our need of one another.

frontmatter.author: African proverb
frontmatter.quote: If you think you're too small to make a difference, try spending the night with a mosquito.

frontmatter.author: Nnedi Okorafor, Binti
frontmatter.quote: They say that when faced with a fight you cannot win, you can never predict what you will do next.

frontmatter.author: African proverb
frontmatter.quote: Wisdom is like a baobab tree; no one individual can embrace it.

frontmatter.author: Rachid Yazami
frontmatter.quote: Trust in yourself and think about having a roadmap for your dream. I always dreamed to be what I am today. At 10 years old I said I want to be a scientist.

frontmatter.author: Prof. Alemseged
frontmatter.quote: Africa is not new to science. It's just that it has forgotten it and that's what we need to revive.

frontmatter.author: Nelson Mandela
frontmatter.quote: What counts in life is not the mere fact that we have lived. It is what difference we have made to the lives of others.

frontmatter.title: Desmond Tanko Jumbam grew up in poverty, he is now a Harvard graduate who is fighting for health equity
frontmatter.subject: Desmond Tanko Jumbam
frontmatter.excerpt: Desmond Tanko grew up in poverty in Cameroon. His tenacity led him to study abroad at the prestigious Harvard Medical School in the United States. He is now fighting for health equity and working on improving health policy and research in Africa.
frontmatter.author: Kaleab Alemayehu Kinfu, Danielle Tchuinkou

frontmatter.title: Fatima Cody Stanford is pioneering work in obesity and health and advocating for equality in medicine
frontmatter.subject: Fatima Cody Stanford
frontmatter.excerpt: Learn about Fatima Cody Stanford's journey of first being taught at home by her maternal grandmother and growing up in Atlanta, Georgio, the cradle of the civil rights movement, shaped her to be more intentional in advancing people of African descent through her pioneering work at Harvard Medical School which has gone to make her work an authority not only in the US but throughout the world.
frontmatter.author: Singatha Xaba

frontmatter.title: Jelani Nelson: A self-starter and a pioneer in the field of algorithms
frontmatter.subject: Jelani Nelson
frontmatter.excerpt: Learn about Jelani Nelson’s journey from how playing computer games inspired him to teach himself how to code — first in HTML and later in C/C++ — that ultimately led him to become a top Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at UC Berkeley, one of the top-tier schools in the United States.
frontmatter.author: Kaleab Alemayehu Kinfu

frontmatter.title: Mireille Kamariza: An award-winning scientist who is changing the equation in the global Tuberculosis crisis
frontmatter.subject: Mireille Kamariza
frontmatter.excerpt: Learn about Mireille Kamariza's journey from growing up in Burundi to becoming an award-winning scientist and a Silicon Valley biotech entrepreneur who was named one of the world's most powerful women by Fortune magazine.
frontmatter.author: Kaleab Alemayehu Kinfu

frontmatter.title: Kenyan Tavneet Suri's research helps to understand the effects of technology on poverty in Africa
frontmatter.subject: Tavneet Suri
frontmatter.excerpt: From Nairobi, Kenya to Yale and MIT in the United States, Dr. Tavneet Suri is leveraging economic research to understand the effects of technology on poverty in Africa. She's bringing her and other scholars in Economics research to policy makers through her online platform [VoxDev](https://voxdev.org/)
frontmatter.author: Awa Gaye

frontmatter.title: Meet Tina Lasisi, the first Black person to graduate with a Ph.D. in Anthropology from Penn State University
frontmatter.subject: Tina Lasisi
frontmatter.excerpt: Learn about Tina Lasisi's journey from growing up in the Netherlands born to Nigerian immigrant parents to becoming the first Black person to graduate with a Ph.D. in Anthropology from Penn State University.
frontmatter.author: Kaleab Alemayehu Kinfu

frontmatter.title: Dr. Youssef Travaly is helping accelerate Africa's transition to an inclusive innovation economy
frontmatter.subject: Youssef Travaly
frontmatter.excerpt: Learn about Youssef Travaly's journey from living in several countries and studying on three continents to developing a 'Brain-Trust' for governmental and non-governmental organizations as the Executive Chairman of AllSightsAfrica.
frontmatter.author: Kaleab Alemayehu Kinfu, Danielle Tchuinkou

frontmatter.title: Meet Nigerian Temiloluwa O. Prioleau, the first Black woman tenure-track faculty in Computer Science in the Ivy League
frontmatter.subject: Temiloluwa O. Prioleau
frontmatter.excerpt: Learn about Temiloluwa O. Prioleau's journey from growing up in Nigeria to becoming a tenure-track Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Dartmouth College, one of the eight Ivy League schools in the United States.
frontmatter.author: Adji Bousso Dieng

frontmatter.title: Ndapa Nakashole is on a mission to teach machines to understand human language
frontmatter.subject: Ndapa Nakashole
frontmatter.excerpt: Learn about Ndapa Nakashole's journey from growing up in Namibia to becoming a tenure-track Assistant Professor of Computer Science at University of California, San Diego.
frontmatter.author: Awa Dieng
